\(p(x)=a_1x^{99}+a_2x^{98}+...+a_{99}x+a_{100}\)

Since \((x_i,y_i)\) for \(1\leq i\leq 100\), then there are 100 linear equations for the coefficient vector

\(\underline{a}=[a_1,a_2,...,a_{100}]^T\)

Therefore, the matrix equation that is satisfied is:

\(\begin{bmatrix} x_1^{99} &x_1^{98} &...&x_1^2 &x_1 &1 \\ x_2^{99}& x_2^{98}&...& x_2^{2}& x_2 & 1\\ & & & & & \\ \vdots & \vdots & & \ddots& & \vdots\\ & & & & & \\ x_{100}^{99}& x_{100}^{98} &...& x_{100}^2 & x_{100}& 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} a_1\\ a_2\\ ...\\ ...\\ ...\\ a_{99}\\ a_{100}\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} y_1\\ y_2\\ ...\\ ...\\ ...\\ y_{99}\\ y_{100} \end{bmatrix}\)

However, since the Vandermonde matrix not very well conditioned (because Vandermonde matrices have large condition numbers, an error in the data points can cause a relatively large error in the solution), it is unlikely that the solution is accurate
